Class RingOfCurrent

  • java.lang.Object
    • teal.core.AbstractElement
      • teal.render.Rendered
        • teal.sim.SimRendered

  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.beans.PropertyChangeListener, java.io.Serializable, java.util.EventListener, HasID, Referenced, TElement, THasPropertyChange, TUpdatable, Integratable, MetaIntegratable, GeneratesB, GeneratesE, HasCurrent, HasInductance, HasResistance, HasRadius, HasBoundingArea, HasColor, HasDirection, HasFog, HasNode3D, HasPosition, HasRotation, IsMoveable, IsPickable, TAbstractRendered, TDrawable, TRendered, HasCollisionController, Constrainable, HasSimEngine, HasMass, HasMomentOfInertia, HasVelocity, PhysicalElement, TSimElement
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Coil

    public class RingOfCurrent
extends EMObject
implements HasRadius, HasCurrent, HasResistance, HasInductance, GeneratesE, GeneratesB, MetaIntegratable
    The ring of current class. This class knows how to generate the electric and magnetic fields of a moving ring carrying current I. The ring also has inductance and resistance. It is more complicated than any other extension of EMObject because it has the ability to integrate the external field due to other magnetic field producing objects in the world over its area, that is to calculate the total external magnetic flux through itself. This is used if we want to calculate the induced current in the ring due to changing flux through the ring due to other objects in the world. Note also that since the ring has finite extent when we come to calculate the force on the ring due to external magnetic fields we have to integrate dF = i dl x B around the perimeter of the ring to get the total force.
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Phillip Bailey
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      protected double f(double x, double y)
      f(x,y) is the dot product of external B fields with the unit vector v, where x and y are the coordinates on the disk of the ring along u1 and u2 respectively.
      protected double flux_d()
      flux_d() is a "shadow-value method" for computing the flux through the ring surface.
      protected double g(double x)
      g(x) is the partial integral of f(x,y) for fixed x and y varying between -SQRT(r^2-x^2) and SQRT(r^2-x^2).

        protected int integrationMode
        If true then all of the external magnetic fields are symmetric about the axis of the ring of current. This simplifies the integration to a one instead of a two dimensional integration.

      • getDipoleMoment

        public javax.vecmath.Vector3d getDipoleMoment()
        Computes the dipole moment of the ring, which is a vector in the direction of the axis of the ring, with magnitude equal to the surface area of the ring multiplied by its current. The current convention is positive counterclockwise with respect to the direction of the dipole moment.
        Returns:
        Dipole moment of the ring.

      • getB

        public javax.vecmath.Vector3d getB(javax.vecmath.Vector3d point)
        Evaluates the magnetic field at the given position. If the point of evaluation is on-axis, a closed form expression is used. Otherwise, the ellipticalIntegral method is used for the evaluation. See Section 3.2 of the TEAL Physics and Mathematics documentation.
        Specified by:
        getB in interface GeneratesB
        Parameters:

      • getBFlux

        public double getBFlux(javax.vecmath.Vector3d point)
        There is a problem with this function if point is a position on the ring itself, needs a fix. Evaluates the magnetic flux function at the given position. We use the flux function as given by equation (3.2.3.1) of the TEAL Physics and Mathematics documentation. Note that we are taking mu naught to be 1 in this expression and multiplying by a factor of 100 simply to make the flux values in a reasonable range. Any change in this factor of 100 should be accompanied by similar changes in anything else used in magnetic flux calculations, e.g. the magnetic dipole.
        Specified by:
        getBFlux in interface GeneratesB
        Parameters:
        point - Position to evaluate the magnetic flux at.
        Returns:
        Magnetic flux value at the given position.

        public void setInducing(boolean x)

      • getDependentValues

        public void getDependentValues(double[] depValues,
                               int offset)
        Description copied from class: PhysicalObject
        The Dependent Variables of a Rotating Object are position,velocity and rotation. We return them in an array, broken down into x, y, and z. We pack x, y, z of position, then x, y, z, of velocity. This order matters in setDependentValues.
        Specified by:
        getDependentValues in interface Integratable
        Overrides:
        getDependentValues in class PhysicalObject

      • setDependentValues

        public void setDependentValues(double[] newValues,
                               int offset)
        Description copied from class: PhysicalObject
        The dependent variables of a rotating object are position,velocity and rotation We unpack x, y, and z for position, then velocity. This order must mirror the one we used to pack these values in getDependentValues RungeKutta4.integrate(Integratable) will invoke this method on us when it has determined new values for our dependent variables.
        Specified by:
        setDependentValues in interface Integratable
        Overrides:
        setDependentValues in class PhysicalObject

      • getDependentDerivatives

        public void getDependentDerivatives(double[] depDerivatvies,
                                    int offset,
                                    double time)
        Description copied from interface: Integratable
        Return the values of the derivatives of your dependent variables, given a set of values for your dependent variables and a specific value of your independent variable. depValues double[] containing values of your dependent variables that you should use to calculate values of dependent derivatives
        Specified by:
        getDependentDerivatives in interface Integratable
        Overrides:
        getDependentDerivatives in class PhysicalObject
        time - double holding the value of the independent variable that you should use to calculate values of dependent derivatives.

      • solveInterdependencies

        public boolean solveInterdependencies()
        Description copied from interface: MetaIntegratable
        Performs a single step towards the solution of interdependent variables.
        Specified by:
        solveInterdependencies in interface MetaIntegratable

      • update

        public void update()
        Description copied from interface: TUpdatable
        Insures that any working values are syncrhronized with the 'published' values, and that PropertyChange and visual changes are propagated. This should not be called in highly compute intensive sections of code, but only at the end of the scene integration.
        Specified by:
        update in interface TUpdatable
        Overrides:
        update in class PhysicalObject

      • flux_d

        protected double flux_d()
        flux_d() is a "shadow-value method" for computing the flux through the ring surface. It can itself call either a single integration (which works for a general system with axial symmetry), or a double integration (which works for all cases, but is extremely slow).

      • setuv

        protected void setuv()
        setuv() is called before the integration begins, to define a unit vector in the direction of the ring (v), and two vectors on the plane of the ring, to define the x and y directions of integration (u1 and u2 respectively).

      • f

        protected double f(double x,
                   double y)
        f(x,y) is the dot product of external B fields with the unit vector v, where x and y are the coordinates on the disk of the ring along u1 and u2 respectively.

      • q

        protected double q(double r)
        q(r) is equivalent to 2*pi*|r|*f(r,0).

      • g

        protected double g(double x)
        g(x) is the partial integral of f(x,y) for fixed x and y varying between -SQRT(r^2-x^2) and SQRT(r^2-x^2). In the double integral, it is integrated itself for x between -r and r, to yield the flux.

      • doubleIntegrate

        protected double doubleIntegrate()

      • singleIntegrate

        protected double singleIntegrate()

      • getExternalFlux

      • getTotalFlux

        public double getTotalFlux()

      • reset

        public void reset()

      • getRotationMatrix

        public javax.vecmath.Matrix3d getRotationMatrix()
        Overloading this method enables using the shadow value for orientation. The evaluation of the dipole moment is thus more accurate. This is also crucial for current induction, since a varying orientation during integration is what allows to evaluate, indirectly, the derivative of the flux.
        Overrides:
        getRotationMatrix in class Rendered

      • getCEIaccuracy

        public double getCEIaccuracy()
        This method gets the accuracy to which we compute the complete elliptic integral for this ring of current in computing its magnetic fields and flux function. Default value is 0.0002
        Returns:
        double representing the accuracy of the CEI calculation

      • setCEIaccuracy

        public void setCEIaccuracy(double accuracy)
        Parameters:
        accuracy - The accuracy of the CEI calculation
        See Also:
        getCEIaccuracy
